factoid: Uncle led the visitors through the anteroom.
Uncle led the visitors into a small hall with a folding table and red chairs.
Uncle led the visitors into the drawing room with a round birchwood table and a sofa.
Uncle led the visitors into Uncle's private room.
Uncle's private room had a tattered sofa.
Uncle's private room had a worn carpet.
Uncle's private room had a portrait of Suvórov.
Uncle's private room had a portrait of the host's father.
Uncle's private room had a portrait of the host's mother.
Uncle's private room had a portrait of Uncle in military uniform.
The study smelled strongly of tobacco and dogs.
Uncle asked the visitors to sit down.
Uncle asked the visitors to make themselves at home.
Uncle went out of the room.
Rugáy came into the room.
Rugáy's back was still muddy.
Rugáy lay down on the sofa.
Rugáy cleaned himself with his tongue and teeth.
There was a passage leading from the study.
The passage had a partition with ragged curtains.
Women's laughter and whispers came from behind the partition.
Natásha took off her wrap.
Nicholas took off his wrap.
Pétya took off his wrap.
Natásha sat down on the sofa.
Nicholas sat down on the sofa.
Pétya sat down on the sofa.
Pétya leaned on his elbow.
Pétya fell asleep at once.
Natásha was silent.
Nicholas was silent.
Natásha's face glowed.
Nicholas's face glowed.
Natásha was hungry.
Nicholas was hungry.
Natásha was very cheerful.
Nicholas was very cheerful.
Natásha looked at Nicholas.
Nicholas looked at Natásha.
Natásha gave Nicholas a wink.
Natásha and Nicholas burst into laughter.
Uncle wore a Cossack coat, blue trousers, and small top boots.
Natásha felt that the costume was just the right thing.
Natásha felt that the costume was not worse than a swallow-tail or frock coat.
Uncle was in high spirits.
Uncle was not offended by the laughter of Nicholas and Natásha.
Uncle joined in the merriment.
Uncle said "That's right, young countess, that's it, come on! I never saw anyone like her!"
Uncle offered Nicholas a pipe with a long stem.
Uncle took down another pipe that had been cut short.
Uncle said "She's ridden all day like a man, and is as fresh as ever!"
A barefooted girl opened the door.
A stout, rosy, good-looking woman of about forty with a double chin and full red lips entered carrying a large loaded tray.
The woman was Uncle's housekeeper.
The woman looked at the visitors with hospitable dignity and cordiality.
The woman bowed respectfully with a pleasant smile.
The woman's stoutness caused her chest and stomach to protrude and her head to throw back.
The woman trod very lightly.
The woman went to the table.
The woman set down the tray on the table.
The woman took from the tray the bottles and various hors d’oeuvres and dishes and arranged them on the table.
The woman finished arranging the items.
The woman stepped aside.
The woman stopped at the door with a smile on her face.
The woman said "Here I am. I am she! Now do you understand 'Uncle'?" to Rostóv.
Nicholas understood the meaning of the housekeeper's expression.
Natásha understood the meaning of the housekeeper's expression.
On the tray was a bottle of herb wine.
On the tray were different kinds of vodka.
On the tray were pickled mushrooms.
On the tray were rye cakes made with buttermilk.
On the tray was honey in the comb.
On the tray was still mead.
On the tray was sparkling mead.
On the tray were apples.
On the tray were raw and roasted nuts.
On the tray were nut-and-honey sweets.
The housekeeper brought a freshly roasted chicken.
The housekeeper brought ham.
The housekeeper brought preserves made with honey.
The housekeeper brought preserves made with sugar.
The food and drinks were the fruit of Anísya Fëdorovna's housekeeping.
Anísya Fëdorovna gathered and prepared the food and drinks.
The smell and taste of the food and drinks had a smack of Anísya Fëdorovna herself.
The smell and taste conveyed a savor of juiciness, cleanliness, whiteness, and pleasant smiles.
The housekeeper said "Take this, little Lady-Countess!"
The housekeeper offered Natásha items one after another.
Natásha ate everything.
Natásha thought she had never seen or eaten such buttermilk cakes.
Natásha thought she had never seen or eaten such aromatic jam.
Natásha thought she had never seen or eaten such honey-and-nut sweets.
Natásha thought she had never seen or eaten such a chicken anywhere.
Anísya Fëdorovna left the room.
